title: How to Make Cauliflower Soup

steps.headline: Prepare the cauliflower.
steps.description: Rinse the cauliflower first, then chop off the leaves and thick stem. Cut the cauliflower into florets, then set it aside.

steps.headline: Bring the water and salt to a boil in a medium-sized saucepan.
steps.description: Fill a medium-sized saucepan with 4 cups (950 milliliters) of water, then add 2 teaspoons of salt. Give the water a stir, then bring it to a boil over medium to medium-high heat.

steps.headline: Add the cauliflower florets, and cook for 4 minutes, or until the cauliflower turns soft and tender.
steps.description: If you have not yet done so, rinse the cauliflower, cut off the stem, then chop it up into florets. Add it to the water, then continue to cook it until it turns soft, about 4 minutes.

steps.headline: Fill a blender or food processor halfway with the cooked cauliflower.
steps.description: Use a slotted spoon to scoop the cauliflower out of the saucepan. Save the salted water, and keep the rest of the florets in the saucepan. You will be puréeing them in batches.

steps.headline: Fill the blender or food processor a quarter of the way with the cooking water.
steps.description: Again, leave the rest of the water and cauliflower in the saucepan. If you'd like, you can keep the saucepan covered to keep the liquid nice and hot.

steps.headline: Purée the cauliflower until it turns smooth.
steps.description: The longer you purée it, the smoother your soup will become. If it is too thick, you can add more cooking water. You may not end up using all of the cooking water.

steps.headline: Pour the mixture into a separate saucepan, then continue puréeing the rest of the cauliflower.
steps.description: How many batches you make will depend on the size of your blender or food processor; most will require only two batches. Pour each batch you complete into the other saucepan. Use caution when opening the blender. The built up heat and pressure may cause splattering. It would be a good idea to open the lid a crack first.

steps.headline: Add some salt and butter.
steps.description: You will need about ½ to 1 teaspoon of salt and 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 grams) of butter. Once you have added in the salt and butter, give the mixture another quick pulse to combine. Alternatively, you can season the soup with some bouillon instead of salt. Chicken or vegetable is recommended.

steps.headline: Bring the soup back to a boil.
steps.description: Stir it until it thickens and the butter melts. If you added in some bouillon, it might be a good idea to use a whisk in stead to help the bouillon mix in better.

steps.headline: Give the soup a final stir, then serve it while it is still hot.
steps.description: There is enough soup to serve 8 people. You can serve it as is, or garnish it with some olive oil and chopped chives. If you have any leftovers, cover them, and store them in the fridge.

steps.headline: Prepare the vegetables.
steps.description: Rinse the cauliflower, cut off the stem and leaves, then chop it into florets. Rinse the carrot, cut off the leaves, then shred it. Lastly, rinse off the celery, then chop it into ¼ to ½-inch (0.64 to 1.27-centimeter) pieces.

steps.headline: Put the vegetables into a large saucepan, then add the water and bouillon.
steps.description: Give everything a stir to combine. You can use either chicken or vegetable bouillon.

steps.headline: Bring the mixture to a boil, then simmer it for 12 to 15 minutes.
steps.description: Turn the heat up to medium or medium-high, and let the water come to a boil. As soon as it starts to boil, reduce the heat to low, then let the water simmer for 12 to 15 minutes. You are ready for the next step when the vegetables turn tender. Do not pour the water out. You will be using this as part of your soup base.

steps.headline: Melt the butter in a separate saucepan.
steps.description: Make sure that the saucepan is large enough to hold the rest of your ingredients, including the milk. Stir the butter occasionally with a rubber spatula to help it melt.

steps.headline: Stir in the flour, salt, and pepper.
steps.description: Use a whisk or fork to mix in the flour so that it doesn't clump up too much. You can vary the amounts of salt and pepper to suit your personal tastes.

steps.headline: Slowly pour in the milk while stirring with a whisk.
steps.description: 2% milk is recommended for this recipe, but you can use whole milk for a richer soup, or fat-free milk for a lighter one. Be sure to stir the mixture well so that the butter and flour mix in evenly.

steps.headline: Boil over medium heat for 2 minutes.
steps.description: Turn the heat up to medium, then wait for the mixture to boil. Let it boil for 2 minutes, stirring occasionally. You are ready for the next step when the mixture thickens.

steps.headline: Reduce the heat, then stir in the Cheddar cheese.
steps.description: Turn the heat down to low, then add the cheese. Stir the mixture with a rubber spatula or wooden spoon until the cheese has melted and mixed evenly into the milk.

steps.headline: Slowly stir the milk mixture into the vegetable mixture.
steps.description: Use a whisk to blend the two mixtures together. Keep stirring until everything is evenly combined.

steps.headline: Serve the soup while it is still hot.
steps.description: You can serve it as is, or you can garnish it with some croutons.

steps.headline: Heat the olive oil in a saucepan over medium heat.
steps.description: Pour 2 tablespoons (30 milliliters) of extra-virgin olive oil into a large saucepan. Turn the heat to medium, then wait for the olive oil to get hot.

steps.headline: Add the onion and garlic, and cook until they turn soft, about 5 minutes.
steps.description: If you have not done so already, chop 1 small onion, and mince 2 cloves of garlic. Add both to the hot oil, and cook them until they become soft. Stir them occasionally with a rubber spatula so that they don't brown.

steps.headline: Add the cauliflower and the chicken stock.
steps.description: If you have not yet done so, rinse the cauliflower, then cup off the stem and leaves. Cut it into florets, then add it to the saucepan along with the chicken stock. If you are vegetarian, or simply don't like chicken, you can use vegetable stock instead. If you cannot find any liquid chicken stock, you can make own by dissolving a bouillon cube or powder in 4 cups (950 milliliters) of hot water. How much bouillon you use depends on the brand that you are using; each brand requires different ratios of bouillon to water, so be sure to read the package.

steps.headline: Simmer the mixture, covered, for about 15 minutes.
steps.description: Reduce the heat to low, and let the mixture simmer for about 15 minutes. You are ready for the next step when the cauliflower turns soft and starts to fall apart.

steps.headline: Take the saucepan off the burner, then purée the mixture.
steps.description: You can do this using a hand-held immersion blender, or you can do it in two batches in a blender or food processor. If you are using a blender, be sure to open the lid a crack after blending to release any built-up pressure.

steps.headline: Stir in the Parmesan cheese.
steps.description: If you used a blender or food processor to purée your soup, pour it back into the saucepan first. Next, add the Parmesan cheese, and stir until it melts and everything is smooth.

steps.headline: Season the soup, if needed, then serve it warm.
steps.description: Give the soup a taste, then add as much salt and pepper as you'd like. Serve the soup while it is still hot.
